newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dlr takes wild ride with Aussie, ends off highs.
newsitem.headline: NZ dlr takes wild ride with Aussie, ends off highs.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar ended off its highs on Wednesday after trading a wide range under the influence of wild fluctuations in the Australian dollar.

The Kiwi fell more than a cent overnight, hitting a low of US$0.7005 as the Australian unit dived three U.S. cents, reflecting a sharp fall in gold prices and fund managers reweighting positions after the currency's strong recent run.
"With a range like 0.7005 through 0.7113, you could say there was something there for everybody, and those that missed out were probably half asleep," an Auckland trader said.
The currency closed at US$0.7084/91 and 67.40 on its Trade-Weighted Index.
"Strong exporter buying took it to its highs, then a bit of profit-taking out of Asia sold it back down," another dealer commented.
He said the market was getting "sick" of political to-ing and fro-ing, with expectations of a final coalition deal now shifting from this week to next.

The caretaker National Party government held a meeting of its MPs, and Labour leaders were meeting New Zealand First after an "exchange of papers" covering both policy issues and allocation of ministerial portfolios.
However, Labour leader Helen Clark said the meeting would certainly not be the last.
Both National and Labour aim to form a coalition government with NZ First after October's general election.
A range of US$0.7060-7110 was expected overnight.
